createdAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job template was created.

jobExecutionsRetryConfig.documentation: The configuration that determines how many retries are allowed for each failure type for a job.

maintenanceWindows.documentation: Allows you to configure an optional maintenance window for the rollout of a job document to all devices in the target group for a job.

destinationPackageVersions.documentation:
The package version Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) that are installed on the device when the job successfully completes. The package version must be in either the Published or Deprecated state when the job deploys. For more information, see Package version lifecycle.

Note:The following Length Constraints relates to a single ARN. Up to 25 package version ARNs are allowed.

templateName.documentation: The unique name of a managed job template, which is required.

templateVersion.documentation: An optional parameter to specify version of a managed template. If not specified, the pre-defined default version is returned.

templateName.documentation: The unique name of a managed template, such as AWS-Reboot.

templateArn.documentation: The unique Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the managed template.

description.documentation: The unique description of a managed template.

environments.documentation: A list of environments that are supported with the managed job template.

documentParameters.documentation:
A map of key-value pairs that you can use as guidance to specify the inputs for creating a job from a managed template.

documentParameters can only be used when creating jobs from Amazon Web Services managed templates. This parameter can't be used with custom job templates or to create jobs from them.

document.documentation: The document schema for a managed job template.

actionName.documentation: The friendly name that uniquely identifies the mitigation action.
The friendly name that uniquely identifies the mitigation action.

actionArn.documentation: The ARN that identifies this migration action.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role used to apply this action.

actionParams.documentation: Parameters that control how the mitigation action is applied, specific to the type of mitigation action.

creationDate.documentation: The date and time when the mitigation action was added to your Amazon Web Services accounts.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date and time when the mitigation action was last changed.

creationDate.documentation: The date when the provisioning template was created.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date when the provisioning template was last modified.

templateBody.documentation: The JSON formatted contents of the provisioning template.

enabled.documentation: True if the provisioning template is enabled, otherwise false.

provisioningRoleArn.documentation: The ARN of the role associated with the provisioning template. This IoT role grants permission to provision a device.

type.documentation: The type you define in a provisioning template. You can create a template with only one type. You can't change the template type after its creation. The default value is FLEET_PROVISIONING. For more information about provisioning template, see: Provisioning template.

creationDate.documentation: The date when the provisioning template version was created.

templateBody.documentation: The JSON formatted contents of the provisioning template version.

isDefaultVersion.documentation: True if the provisioning template version is the default version.

scheduledAuditName.documentation: The name of the scheduled audit whose information you want to get.

frequency.documentation: How often the scheduled audit takes place, either one of DAILY, WEEKLY, BIWEEKLY, or MONTHLY. The start time of each audit is determined by the system.

dayOfMonth.documentation: The day of the month on which the scheduled audit takes place. This is will be 1 through 31 or LAST. If days 29-31 are specified, and the month does not have that many days, the audit takes place on the LAST day of the month.

dayOfWeek.documentation: The day of the week on which the scheduled audit takes place, either one of SUN, MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI, or SAT.

targetCheckNames.documentation: Which checks are performed during the scheduled audit. Checks must be enabled for your account. (Use DescribeAccountAuditConfiguration to see the list of all checks, including those that are enabled or use UpdateAccountAuditConfiguration to select which checks are enabled.)

securityProfileName.documentation: The name of the security profile whose information you want to get.

securityProfileDescription.documentation: A description of the security profile (associated with the security profile when it was created or updated).

behaviors.documentation: Specifies the behaviors that, when violated by a device (thing), cause an alert.

alertTargets.documentation: Where the alerts are sent. (Alerts are always sent to the console.)

additionalMetricsToRetain.documentation:
Please use DescribeSecurityProfileResponse$additionalMetricsToRetainV2 instead.

A list of metrics whose data is retained (stored). By default, data is retained for any metric used in the profile's behaviors, but it is also retained for any metric specified here.

additionalMetricsToRetainV2.documentation: A list of metrics whose data is retained (stored). By default, data is retained for any metric used in the profile's behaviors, but it is also retained for any metric specified here.

version.documentation: The version of the security profile. A new version is generated whenever the security profile is updated.

creationDate.documentation: The time the security profile was created.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The time the security profile was last modified.

metricsExportConfig.documentation: Specifies the MQTT topic and role ARN required for metric export.

queryString.documentation: The dynamic thing group search query string.

status.documentation: The dynamic thing group status.

The task ID.

creationDate.documentation: The task creation date.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date when the task was last modified.

inputFileBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket that contains the input file.

roleArn.documentation: The role ARN that grants access to the input file bucket.

status.documentation: The status of the bulk thing provisioning task.

failureCount.documentation: The number of things that failed to be provisioned.

percentageProgress.documentation: The progress of the bulk provisioning task expressed as a percentage.

thingName.documentation: The name of the thing.

defaultClientId.documentation:
The default MQTT client ID. For a typical device, the thing name is also used as the default MQTT client ID. Although we dont require a mapping between a thing's registry name and its use of MQTT client IDs, certificates, or shadow state, we recommend that you choose a thing name and use it as the MQTT client ID for the registry and the Device Shadow service.

This lets you better organize your IoT fleet without removing the flexibility of the underlying device certificate model or shadows.

thingName.documentation: The name of the thing.

thingId.documentation: The ID of the thing to describe.

thingArn.documentation: The ARN of the thing to describe.

version.documentation:
The current version of the thing record in the registry.

To avoid unintentional changes to the information in the registry, you can pass the version information in the expectedVersion parameter of the UpdateThing and DeleteThing calls.

billingGroupName.documentation: The name of the billing group the thing belongs to.

thingTypeProperties.documentation: The ThingTypeProperties contains information about the thing type including description, a list of searchable thing attribute names, and MQTT5 configuration.

thingTypeMetadata.documentation: The ThingTypeMetadata contains additional information about the thing type including: creation date and time, a value indicating whether the thing type is deprecated, and a date and time when it was deprecated.

s3Destination.documentation: Describes the location in S3 of the updated firmware.

Destination.documentation: Describes the location of the updated firmware.

target.documentation: The target from which the policy will be detached.

policyName.documentation: The name of the policy to detach.

principal.documentation:
The principal.

Valid principals are CertificateArn (arn:aws:iot:region:accountId:cert/certificateId), thingGroupArn (arn:aws:iot:region:accountId:thinggroup/groupName) and CognitoId (region:id).

securityProfileTargetArn.documentation: The ARN of the thing group from which the security profile is detached.

thingName.documentation: The name of the thing.

principal.documentation: If the principal is a certificate, this value must be ARN of the certificate. If the principal is an Amazon Cognito identity, this value must be the ID of the Amazon Cognito identity.

taskId.documentation: The unique identifier of the task.

violationId.documentation: The unique identifier of the violation.

actionName.documentation: The friendly name that uniquely identifies the mitigation action.

thingName.documentation: The name of the thing.

executionStartDate.documentation: The date a mitigation action was started.

executionEndDate.documentation: The date a mitigation action ended.

status.documentation: The status of a mitigation action.

errorCode.documentation: The error code of a mitigation action.

message.documentation: The message of a mitigation action.

DetectMitigationActionExecution.documentation: Describes which mitigation actions should be executed.

DetectMitigationActionsTaskStatistics.documentation: The statistics of a mitigation action task.

taskId.documentation: The unique identifier of the task.

target.documentation: Specifies the ML Detect findings to which the mitigation actions are applied.

violationEventOccurrenceRange.documentation: Specifies the time period of which violation events occurred between.

taskStatistics.documentation: The statistics of a mitigation action task.

DetectMitigationActionsTaskSummary.documentation: The summary of the mitigation action tasks.

violationIds.documentation: The unique identifiers of the violations.

securityProfileName.documentation: The name of the security profile.

DetectMitigationActionsTaskTarget.documentation: The target of a mitigation action task.

ruleName.documentation: The name of the rule to disable.

packageName.documentation: The name of the new software package.

versionName.documentation: The name of the new package version.

clientToken.documentation: A unique case-sensitive identifier that you can provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. Don't reuse this client token if a new idempotent request is required.

key.documentation: Key of the map field containing the patterns that need to be replaced in a managed template job document schema.

description.documentation: Description of the map field containing the patterns that need to be replaced in a managed template job document schema.

regex.documentation: A regular expression of the patterns that need to be replaced in a managed template job document schema.

example.documentation: An example illustrating a pattern that need to be replaced in a managed template job document schema.

optional.documentation: Specifies whether a pattern that needs to be replaced in a managed template job document schema is optional or required.

DocumentParameter.documentation:
A map of key-value pairs containing the patterns that need to be replaced in a managed template job document schema. You can use the description of each key as a guidance to specify the inputs during runtime when creating a job.

documentParameters can only be used when creating jobs from Amazon Web Services managed templates. This parameter can't be used with custom job templates or to create jobs from them.

domainConfigurationName.documentation: The name of the domain configuration. This value must be unique to a region.

serviceType.documentation: The type of service delivered by the endpoint.

DomainConfigurationSummary.documentation:
The summary of a domain configuration. A domain configuration specifies custom IoT-specific information about a domain. A domain configuration can be associated with an Amazon Web Services-managed domain (for example, dbc123defghijk.iot.us-west-2.amazonaws.com), a customer managed domain, or a default endpoint.

  • Data

  • Jobs

  • CredentialProvider

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that grants access to the DynamoDB table.

operation.documentation: The type of operation to be performed. This follows the substitution template, so it can be ${operation}, but the substitution must result in one of the following: INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE.

hashKeyType.documentation: The hash key type. Valid values are "STRING" or "NUMBER"

rangeKeyType.documentation: The range key type. Valid values are "STRING" or "NUMBER"

payloadField.documentation: The action payload. This name can be customized.

DynamoDBAction.documentation:
Describes an action to write to a DynamoDB table.

The tableName, hashKeyField, and rangeKeyField values must match the values used when you created the table.

The hashKeyValue and rangeKeyvalue fields use a substitution template syntax. These templates provide data at runtime. The syntax is as follows: ${sql-expression}.

You can specify any valid expression in a WHERE or SELECT clause, including JSON properties, comparisons, calculations, and functions. For example, the following field uses the third level of the topic:

"hashKeyValue": "${topic(3)}"

The following field uses the timestamp:

"rangeKeyValue": "${timestamp()}"

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that grants access to the DynamoDB table.

putItem.documentation:
Specifies the DynamoDB table to which the message data will be written. For example:

{ "dynamoDBv2": { "roleArn": "aws:iam:12341251:my-role" "putItem": { "tableName": "my-table" } } }

Each attribute in the message payload will be written to a separate column in the DynamoDB database.

DynamoDBv2Action.documentation:
Describes an action to write to a DynamoDB table.

This DynamoDB action writes each attribute in the message payload into it's own column in the DynamoDB table.

EffectivePolicy.documentation: The policy that has the effect on the authorization results.

roleArn.documentation: The IAM role ARN that has access to OpenSearch.

index.documentation: The index where you want to store your data.

type.documentation: The type of document you are storing.

id.documentation: The unique identifier for the document you are storing.

ElasticsearchAction.documentation:
Describes an action that writes data to an Amazon OpenSearch Service domain.

The Elasticsearch action can only be used by existing rule actions. To create a new rule action or to update an existing rule action, use the OpenSearch rule action instead. For more information, see OpenSearchAction.

roleArnForLogging.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role used for logging.

logLevel.documentation: Specifies the type of information to be logged.

EnableIoTLoggingParams.documentation: Parameters used when defining a mitigation action that enable Amazon Web Services IoT Core logging.

ruleName.documentation: The name of the topic rule to enable.

baseRatePerMinute.documentation: The minimum number of things that will be notified of a pending job, per minute at the start of job rollout. This parameter allows you to define the initial rate of rollout.

incrementFactor.documentation:
The exponential factor to increase the rate of rollout for a job.

Amazon Web Services IoT Core supports up to one digit after the decimal (for example, 1.5, but not 1.55).

rateIncreaseCriteria.documentation: The criteria to initiate the increase in rate of rollout for a job.

ExponentialRolloutRate.documentation: Allows you to create an exponential rate of rollout for a job.

Field.documentation: Describes the name and data type at a field.

stream.documentation: The stream that contains the OTA update.

s3Location.documentation: The location of the updated firmware in S3.

roleArn.documentation: The IAM role that grants access to the Amazon Kinesis Firehose stream.

separator.documentation: A character separator that will be used to separate records written to the Firehose stream. Valid values are: '\n' (newline), '\t' (tab), '\r\n' (Windows newline), ',' (comma).

batchMode.documentation:
Whether to deliver the Kinesis Data Firehose stream as a batch by using PutRecordBatch . The default value is false.

When batchMode is true and the rule's SQL statement evaluates to an Array, each Array element forms one record in the PutRecordBatch request. The resulting array can't have more than 500 records.

FirehoseAction.documentation: Describes an action that writes data to an Amazon Kinesis Firehose stream.

FleetMetricNameAndArn.documentation: The name and ARN of a fleet metric.

name.documentation: The name of the geolocation target field. If the target field is part of a named shadow, you must select the named shadow using the namedShadow filter.

order.documentation: The order of the geolocation target field. This field is optional. The default value is LatLon.

GeoLocationTarget.documentation: A geolocation target that you select to index. Each geolocation target contains a name and order key-value pair that specifies the geolocation target fields.

securityProfileName.documentation: The name of the security profile.

maxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to return at one time. The default is 10.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results.

summaries.documentation: A list of all ML Detect behaviors and their model status for a given Security Profile.

nextToken.documentation: A token that can be used to retrieve the next set of results, or null if there are no additional results.

indexName.documentation: The name of the index to search.

bucketsAggregationType.documentation: The basic control of the response shape and the bucket aggregation type to perform.

totalCount.documentation: The total number of things that fit the query string criteria.

buckets.documentation:
The main part of the response with a list of buckets. Each bucket contains a keyValue and a count.

keyValue: The aggregation field value counted for the particular bucket.

count: The number of documents that have that value.

indexName.documentation: The name of the index to search.

cardinality.documentation: The approximate count of unique values that match the query.

executionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the command execution. This information is returned as a response of the StartCommandExecution API request.

targetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the device on which the command execution is being performed.

includeResult.documentation: Can be used to specify whether to include the result of the command execution in the GetCommandExecution API response. Your device can use this field to provide additional information about the command execution. You only need to specify this field when using the AWS-IoT namespace.

executionId.documentation: The unique identifier of the command execution.

commandArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the command. For example, arn:aws:iot:<region>:<accountid>:command/<commandId>

targetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the device on which the command execution is being performed.

status.documentation: The status of the command execution. After your devices receive the command and start performing the operations specified in the command, it can use the UpdateCommandExecution MQTT API to update the status information.

statusReason.documentation: Your devices can use this parameter to provide additional context about the status of a command execution using a reason code and description.

result.documentation:
The result value for the current state of the command execution. The status provides information about the progress of the command execution. The device can use the result field to share additional details about the execution such as a return value of a remote function call.

If you use the AWS-IoT-FleetWise namespace, then this field is not applicable in the API response.

parameters.documentation: The list of parameters that the StartCommandExecution API used when performing the command on the device.

executionTimeoutSeconds.documentation: Specifies the amount of time in seconds that the device can take to finish a command execution. A timer starts when the command execution is created. If the command execution status is not set to another terminal state before the timer expires, it will automatically update to TIMED_OUT.

createdAt.documentation: The timestamp, when the command execution was created.

lastUpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp, when the command execution was last updated.

startedAt.documentation: The timestamp, when the command execution was started.

completedAt.documentation: The timestamp, when the command execution was completed.

timeToLive.documentation: The time to live (TTL) parameter that indicates the duration for which executions will be retained in your account. The default value is six months.

commandId.documentation: The unique identifier of the command for which you want to retrieve information.

commandArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the command. For example, arn:aws:iot:<region>:<accountid>:command/<commandId>

displayName.documentation: The user-friendly name in the console for the command.

description.documentation: A short text description of the command.

mandatoryParameters.documentation: A list of parameters for the command created.

payload.documentation: The payload object that you provided for the command.

roleArn.documentation: The IAM role that you provided when creating the command with AWS-IoT-FleetWise as the namespace.

createdAt.documentation: The timestamp, when the command was created.

lastUpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp, when the command was last updated.

deprecated.documentation: Indicates whether the command has been deprecated.

pendingDeletion.documentation: Indicates whether the command is being deleted.

principal.documentation: The principal. Valid principals are CertificateArn (arn:aws:iot:region:accountId:cert/certificateId), thingGroupArn (arn:aws:iot:region:accountId:thinggroup/groupName) and CognitoId (region:id).

thingName.documentation: The thing name.

jobId.documentation: The unique identifier you assigned to this job when it was created.

beforeSubstitution.documentation: Provides a view of the job document before and after the substitution parameters have been resolved with their exact values.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that grants access.

versionUpdateByJobsConfig.documentation: The version that is associated to a specific job.

packageName.documentation: The name of the target software package.

defaultVersionName.documentation: The name of the default package version.

creationDate.documentation: The date the package was created.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date when the package was last updated.

versionName.documentation: The name of the target package version.

attributes.documentation: Metadata that were added to the package version that can be used to define a package versions configuration.

artifact.documentation: The various components that make up a software package version.

status.documentation: The status associated to the package version. For more information, see Package version lifecycle.

errorReason.documentation: Error reason for a package version failure during creation or update.

creationDate.documentation: The date when the package version was created.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date when the package version was last updated.

sbom.documentation: The software bill of materials for a software package version.

sbomValidationStatus.documentation: The status of the validation for a new software bill of materials added to a software package version.

recipe.documentation: The inline job document associated with a software package version used for a quick job deployment.

indexName.documentation: The name of the index to search.

percentiles.documentation: The percentile values of the aggregated fields.

policyDocument.documentation: The JSON document that describes the policy.

creationDate.documentation: The date the policy was created.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date the policy was last modified.

policyDocument.documentation: The JSON document that describes the policy.

isDefaultVersion.documentation: Specifies whether the policy version is the default.

creationDate.documentation: The date the policy was created.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date the policy was last modified.

generationId.documentation: The generation ID of the policy version.

indexName.documentation: The name of the index to search. The default value is AWS_Things.

queryString.documentation: The query used to search. You can specify "*" for the query string to get the count of all indexed things in your Amazon Web Services account.

queryVersion.documentation: The version of the query used to search.

statistics.documentation: The statistics returned by the Fleet Indexing service based on the query and aggregation field.

thingName.documentation: The name of your IoT thing.
The name of your IoT thing.

connected.documentation: A Boolean that indicates the connectivity status.

timestamp.documentation: The timestamp of when the event occurred.

disconnectReason.documentation: The reason why the client is disconnecting.

arn.documentation: The ARN of the topic rule destination.

roleArn.documentation: The IAM role ARN IoT uses to write to your CloudWatch logs.

GroupNameAndArn.documentation: The name and ARN of a group.

url.documentation: The endpoint URL. If substitution templates are used in the URL, you must also specify a confirmationUrl. If this is a new destination, a new TopicRuleDestination is created if possible.

confirmationUrl.documentation: The URL to which IoT sends a confirmation message. The value of the confirmation URL must be a prefix of the endpoint URL. If you do not specify a confirmation URL IoT uses the endpoint URL as the confirmation URL. If you use substitution templates in the confirmationUrl, you must create and enable topic rule destinations that match each possible value of the substitution template before traffic is allowed to your endpoint URL.

headers.documentation: The HTTP headers to send with the message data.

auth.documentation: The authentication method to use when sending data to an HTTPS endpoint.

value.documentation: The HTTP header value. Substitution templates are supported.

sigv4.documentation: Use Sig V4 authorization. For more information, see Signature Version 4 Signing Process.

HttpAuthorization.documentation: The authorization method used to send messages.

headers.documentation: The header keys and values in an HTTP authorization request.

queryString.documentation: The query string keys and values in an HTTP authorization request.

HttpContext.documentation: Specifies the HTTP context to use for the test authorizer request.

confirmationUrl.documentation: The URL IoT uses to confirm ownership of or access to the topic rule destination URL.

HttpUrlDestinationConfiguration.documentation: HTTP URL destination configuration used by the topic rule's HTTP action.

confirmationUrl.documentation: The URL used to confirm the HTTP topic rule destination URL.
The URL used to confirm ownership of or access to the HTTP topic rule destination URL.

policies.documentation: Policies that don't contain a matching allow or deny statement for the specified action on the specified resource.

ImplicitDeny.documentation: Information that implicitly denies authorization. When policy doesn't explicitly deny or allow an action on a resource it is considered an implicit deny.

namedShadowNames.documentation: The shadow names that you select to index. The default maximum number of shadow names for indexing is 10. To increase the limit, see Amazon Web Services IoT Device Management Quotas in the Amazon Web Services General Reference.

geoLocations.documentation: The list of geolocation targets that you select to index. The default maximum number of geolocation targets for indexing is 1. To increase the limit, see Amazon Web Services IoT Device Management Quotas in the Amazon Web Services General Reference.

IndexingFilter.documentation:
Provides additional selections for named shadows and geolocation data.

To add named shadows to your fleet indexing configuration, set namedShadowIndexingMode to be ON and specify your shadow names in namedShadowNames filter.

To add geolocation data to your fleet indexing configuration:

  • If you store geolocation data in a class/unnamed shadow, set thingIndexingMode to be REGISTRY_AND_SHADOW and specify your geolocation data in geoLocations filter.

  • If you store geolocation data in a named shadow, set namedShadowIndexingMode to be ON, add the shadow name in namedShadowNames filter, and specify your geolocation data in geoLocations filter. For more information, see Managing fleet indexing.

InternalServerException.documentation: Internal error from the service that indicates an unexpected error or that the service is unavailable.

InvalidStateTransitionException.documentation: An attempt was made to change to an invalid state, for example by deleting a job or a job execution which is "IN_PROGRESS" without setting the force parameter.

channelArn.documentation: (deprecated) The ARN of the IoT Analytics channel to which message data will be sent.

channelName.documentation: The name of the IoT Analytics channel to which message data will be sent.

batchMode.documentation:
Whether to process the action as a batch. The default value is false.

When batchMode is true and the rule SQL statement evaluates to an Array, each Array element is delivered as a separate message when passed by BatchPutMessage to the IoT Analytics channel. The resulting array can't have more than 100 messages.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the role which has a policy that grants IoT Analytics permission to send message data via IoT Analytics (iotanalytics:BatchPutMessage).

IotAnalyticsAction.documentation: Sends message data to an IoT Analytics channel.

inputName.documentation: The name of the IoT Events input.

messageId.documentation:
The ID of the message. The default messageId is a new UUID value.

When batchMode is true, you can't specify a messageId--a new UUID value will be assigned.

Assign a value to this property to ensure that only one input (message) with a given messageId will be processed by an IoT Events detector.

batchMode.documentation:
Whether to process the event actions as a batch. The default value is false.

When batchMode is true, you can't specify a messageId.

When batchMode is true and the rule SQL statement evaluates to an Array, each Array element is treated as a separate message when it's sent to IoT Events by calling BatchPutMessage . The resulting array can't have more than 10 messages.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the role that grants IoT permission to send an input to an IoT Events detector. ("Action":"iotevents:BatchPutMessage").

IotEventsAction.documentation: Sends an input to an IoT Events detector.

putAssetPropertyValueEntries.documentation: A list of asset property value entries.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the role that grants IoT permission to send an asset property value to IoT SiteWise. ("Action": "iotsitewise:BatchPutAssetPropertyValue"). The trust policy can restrict access to specific asset hierarchy paths.

IotSiteWiseAction.documentation: Describes an action to send data from an MQTT message that triggered the rule to IoT SiteWise asset properties.

jobArn.documentation: An ARN identifying the job with format "arn:aws:iot:region:account:job/jobId".

jobId.documentation: The unique identifier you assigned to this job when it was created.

targetSelection.documentation:
Specifies whether the job will continue to run (CONTINUOUS), or will be complete after all those things specified as targets have completed the job (SNAPSHOT). If continuous, the job may also be run on a thing when a change is detected in a target. For example, a job will run on a device when the thing representing the device is added to a target group, even after the job was completed by all things originally in the group.

We recommend that you use continuous jobs instead of snapshot jobs for dynamic thing group targets. By using continuous jobs, devices that join the group receive the job execution even after the job has been created.

status.documentation: The status of the job, one of IN_PROGRESS, CANCELED, DELETION_IN_PROGRESS or COMPLETED.

forceCanceled.documentation: Will be true if the job was canceled with the optional force parameter set to true.

reasonCode.documentation: If the job was updated, provides the reason code for the update.

comment.documentation: If the job was updated, describes the reason for the update.

targets.documentation: A list of IoT things and thing groups to which the job should be sent.

description.documentation: A short text description of the job.

jobExecutionsRolloutConfig.documentation: Allows you to create a staged rollout of a job.

abortConfig.documentation: Configuration for criteria to abort the job.

createdAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job was created.

lastUpdatedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job was last updated.

completedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job was completed.

timeoutConfig.documentation: Specifies the amount of time each device has to finish its execution of the job. A timer is started when the job execution status is set to IN_PROGRESS. If the job execution status is not set to another terminal state before the timer expires, it will be automatically set to TIMED_OUT.

namespaceId.documentation:
The namespace used to indicate that a job is a customer-managed job.

When you specify a value for this parameter, Amazon Web Services IoT Core sends jobs notifications to MQTT topics that contain the value in the following format.

$aws/things/THING_NAME/jobs/JOB_ID/notify-namespace-NAMESPACE_ID/

The namespaceId feature is only supported by IoT Greengrass at this time. For more information, see Setting up IoT Greengrass core devices.

jobTemplateArn.documentation: The ARN of the job template used to create the job.

jobExecutionsRetryConfig.documentation: The configuration for the criteria to retry the job.

documentParameters.documentation:
A key-value map that pairs the patterns that need to be replaced in a managed template job document schema. You can use the description of each key as a guidance to specify the inputs during runtime when creating a job.

documentParameters can only be used when creating jobs from Amazon Web Services managed templates. This parameter can't be used with custom job templates or to create jobs from them.

isConcurrent.documentation: Indicates whether a job is concurrent. Will be true when a job is rolling out new job executions or canceling previously created executions, otherwise false.

schedulingConfig.documentation: The configuration that allows you to schedule a job for a future date and time in addition to specifying the end behavior for each job execution.

scheduledJobRollouts.documentation: Displays the next seven maintenance window occurrences and their start times.

destinationPackageVersions.documentation:
The package version Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) that are installed on the device when the job successfully completes. The package version must be in either the Published or Deprecated state when the job deploys. For more information, see Package version lifecycle.The package version must be in either the Published or Deprecated state when the job deploys. For more information, see Package version lifecycle.

Note:The following Length Constraints relates to a single ARN. Up to 25 package version ARNs are allowed.

Job.documentation: The Job object contains details about a job.

jobId.documentation: The unique identifier you assigned to the job when it was created.

status.documentation: The status of the job execution (IN_PROGRESS, QUEUED, FAILED, SUCCEEDED, TIMED_OUT, CANCELED, or REJECTED).

forceCanceled.documentation: Will be true if the job execution was canceled with the optional force parameter set to true.

statusDetails.documentation: A collection of name/value pairs that describe the status of the job execution.

thingArn.documentation: The ARN of the thing on which the job execution is running.

queuedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job execution was queued.

startedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job execution started.

lastUpdatedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job execution was last updated.

executionNumber.documentation: A string (consisting of the digits "0" through "9") which identifies this particular job execution on this particular device. It can be used in commands which return or update job execution information.

versionNumber.documentation: The version of the job execution. Job execution versions are incremented each time they are updated by a device.

approximateSecondsBeforeTimedOut.documentation: The estimated number of seconds that remain before the job execution status will be changed to TIMED_OUT. The timeout interval can be anywhere between 1 minute and 7 days (1 to 10080 minutes). The actual job execution timeout can occur up to 60 seconds later than the estimated duration. This value will not be included if the job execution has reached a terminal status.

JobExecution.documentation: The job execution object represents the execution of a job on a particular device.

status.documentation: The status of the job execution.

queuedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job execution was queued.

startedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job execution started.

lastUpdatedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job execution was last updated.

executionNumber.documentation: A string (consisting of the digits "0" through "9") which identifies this particular job execution on this particular device. It can be used later in commands which return or update job execution information.

retryAttempt.documentation: The number that indicates how many retry attempts have been completed for this job on this device.

thingArn.documentation: The ARN of the thing on which the job execution is running.

jobExecutionSummary.documentation: Contains a subset of information about a job execution.

JobExecutionSummaryForJob.documentation: Contains a summary of information about job executions for a specific job.

jobId.documentation: The unique identifier you assigned to this job when it was created.

jobExecutionSummary.documentation: Contains a subset of information about a job execution.

JobExecutionSummaryForThing.documentation: The job execution summary for a thing.

criteriaList.documentation: The list of criteria that determines how many retries are allowed for each failure type for a job.

JobExecutionsRetryConfig.documentation: The configuration that determines how many retries are allowed for each failure type for a job.

maximumPerMinute.documentation: The maximum number of things that will be notified of a pending job, per minute. This parameter allows you to create a staged rollout.

exponentialRate.documentation: The rate of increase for a job rollout. This parameter allows you to define an exponential rate for a job rollout.

JobExecutionsRolloutConfig.documentation: Allows you to create a staged rollout of a job.

processingTargets.documentation: The target devices to which the job execution is being rolled out. This value will be null after the job execution has finished rolling out to all the target devices.

numberOfCanceledThings.documentation: The number of things that cancelled the job.

numberOfSucceededThings.documentation: The number of things which successfully completed the job.

numberOfFailedThings.documentation: The number of things that failed executing the job.

numberOfRejectedThings.documentation: The number of things that rejected the job.

numberOfQueuedThings.documentation: The number of things that are awaiting execution of the job.

numberOfInProgressThings.documentation: The number of things currently executing the job.

numberOfRemovedThings.documentation: The number of things that are no longer scheduled to execute the job because they have been deleted or have been removed from the group that was a target of the job.

numberOfTimedOutThings.documentation: The number of things whose job execution status is TIMED_OUT.

jobId.documentation: The unique identifier you assigned to this job when it was created.

targetSelection.documentation:
Specifies whether the job will continue to run (CONTINUOUS), or will be complete after all those things specified as targets have completed the job (SNAPSHOT). If continuous, the job may also be run on a thing when a change is detected in a target. For example, a job will run on a thing when the thing is added to a target group, even after the job was completed by all things originally in the group.

We recommend that you use continuous jobs instead of snapshot jobs for dynamic thing group targets. By using continuous jobs, devices that join the group receive the job execution even after the job has been created.

status.documentation: The job summary status.

createdAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job was created.

lastUpdatedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job was last updated.

completedAt.documentation: The time, in seconds since the epoch, when the job completed.

isConcurrent.documentation: Indicates whether a job is concurrent. Will be true when a job is rolling out new job executions or canceling previously created executions, otherwise false.

jobTemplateId.documentation: The unique identifier of the job template.

JobTemplateSummary.documentation: An object that contains information about the job template.

topic.documentation: The Kafka topic for messages to be sent to the Kafka broker.

clientProperties.documentation: Properties of the Apache Kafka producer client.

headers.documentation: The list of Kafka headers that you specify.

KafkaAction.documentation: Send messages to an Amazon Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka (Amazon MSK) or self-managed Apache Kafka cluster.

KafkaActionHeader.documentation:
Specifies a Kafka header using key-value pairs when you create a Rules Kafka Action. You can use these headers to route data from IoT clients to downstream Kafka clusters without modifying your message payload.

For more information about Rule's Kafka action, see Apache Kafka.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that grants access to the Amazon Kinesis stream.

streamName.documentation: The name of the Amazon Kinesis stream.

securityProfileName.documentation: The name of the Device Defender security profile for which violations are listed.

listSuppressedAlerts.documentation: A list of all suppressed alerts.

verificationState.documentation: The verification state of the violation (detect alarm).

taskStatus.documentation: A filter to limit the output to audits with the specified completion status: can be one of "IN_PROGRESS", "COMPLETED", "FAILED", or "CANCELED".

By default, the API returns all commands in the descending order based on the start time or completion time of the executions, that are determined by the startTimeFilter and completeTimeFilter parameters.

startedTimeFilter.documentation: List all command executions that started any time before or after the date and time that you specify. The date and time uses the format yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm.

completedTimeFilter.documentation: List all command executions that completed any time before or after the date and time that you specify. The date and time uses the format yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm.

targetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the target device. You can use this information to list all command executions for a particular device.

commandArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Number (ARN) of the command. You can use this information to list all command executions for a particular command.

namespace.documentation: The namespace of the command. By default, the API returns all commands that have been created for both AWS-IoT and AWS-IoT-FleetWise namespaces. You can override this default value if you want to return all commands that have been created only for a specific namespace.

commandParameterName.documentation: A filter that can be used to display the list of commands that have a specific command parameter name.

The namespace used to indicate that a job is a customer-managed job.

When you specify a value for this parameter, Amazon Web Services IoT Core sends jobs notifications to MQTT topics that contain the value in the following format.

$aws/things/THING_NAME/jobs/JOB_ID/notify-namespace-NAMESPACE_ID/

The namespaceId feature is only supported by IoT Greengrass at this time. For more information, see Setting up IoT Greengrass core devices.

targetSelection.documentation:
Specifies whether the job will continue to run (CONTINUOUS), or will be complete after all those things specified as targets have completed the job (SNAPSHOT). If continuous, the job may also be run on a thing when a change is detected in a target. For example, a job will run on a thing when the thing is added to a target group, even after the job was completed by all things originally in the group.

We recommend that you use continuous jobs instead of snapshot jobs for dynamic thing group targets. By using continuous jobs, devices that join the group receive the job execution even after the job has been created.

timestamp.documentation: The time that the location data was sampled. The default value is the time the MQTT message was processed.

latitude.documentation: A string that evaluates to a double value that represents the latitude of the device's location.

longitude.documentation: A string that evaluates to a double value that represents the longitude of the device's location.

LocationAction.documentation: The Amazon Location rule action sends device location updates from an MQTT message to an Amazon Location tracker resource.

value.documentation: An expression that returns a long epoch time value.

unit.documentation:
The precision of the timestamp value that results from the expression described in value.

Valid values: SECONDS | MILLISECONDS | MICROSECONDS | NANOSECONDS. The default is MILLISECONDS.

LocationTimestamp.documentation: Describes how to interpret an application-defined timestamp value from an MQTT message payload and the precision of that value.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that grants access.

confidenceLevel.documentation: The sensitivity of anomalous behavior evaluation. Can be Low, Medium, or High.

MachineLearningDetectionConfig.documentation: The configuration of an ML Detect Security Profile.

durationInMinutes.documentation: Displays the duration of the next maintenance window.

MaintenanceWindow.documentation: An optional configuration within the SchedulingConfig to setup a recurring maintenance window with a predetermined start time and duration for the rollout of a job document to all devices in a target group for a job.

templateArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for a managed template.

templateName.documentation: The unique Name for a managed template.

environments.documentation: A list of environments that are supported with the managed job template.

ManagedJobTemplateSummary.documentation: An object that contains information about the managed template.

timestamp.documentation: The time the metric value was reported.

operator.documentation: Defines how the dimensionValues of a dimension are interpreted. For example, for dimension type TOPIC_FILTER, the IN operator, a message will be counted only if its topic matches one of the topic filters. With NOT_IN operator, a message will be counted only if it doesn't match any of the topic filters. The operator is optional: if it's not provided (is null), it will be interpreted as IN.

metricDimension.documentation: The dimension of a metric. This can't be used with custom metrics.

exportMetric.documentation: The value indicates exporting metrics related to the MetricToRetain when it's true.

MetricToRetain.documentation: The metric you want to retain. Dimensions are optional.

count.documentation: If the comparisonOperator calls for a numeric value, use this to specify that numeric value to be compared with the metric.

cidrs.documentation: If the comparisonOperator calls for a set of CIDRs, use this to specify that set to be compared with the metric.

ports.documentation: If the comparisonOperator calls for a set of ports, use this to specify that set to be compared with the metric.

number.documentation: The numeral value of a metric.

numbers.documentation: The numeral values of a metric.

strings.documentation: The string values of a metric.

MetricValue.documentation: The value to be compared with the metric.

mqttTopic.documentation: The MQTT topic that Device Defender Detect should publish messages to for metrics export.

roleArn.documentation: This role ARN has permission to publish MQTT messages, after which Device Defender Detect can assume the role and publish messages on your behalf.

name.documentation: A user-friendly name for the mitigation action.

id.documentation: A unique identifier for the mitigation action.

roleArn.documentation: The IAM role ARN used to apply this mitigation action.

actionParams.documentation: The set of parameters for this mitigation action. The parameters vary, depending on the kind of action you apply.

MitigationAction.documentation: Describes which changes should be applied as part of a mitigation action.

actionName.documentation: The friendly name of the mitigation action.

actionArn.documentation: The IAM role ARN used to apply this mitigation action.

creationDate.documentation: The date when this mitigation action was created.

MitigationActionIdentifier.documentation: Information that identifies a mitigation action. This information is returned by ListMitigationActions.

updateDeviceCertificateParams.documentation: Parameters to define a mitigation action that changes the state of the device certificate to inactive.

updateCACertificateParams.documentation: Parameters to define a mitigation action that changes the state of the CA certificate to inactive.

addThingsToThingGroupParams.documentation: Parameters to define a mitigation action that moves devices associated with a certificate to one or more specified thing groups, typically for quarantine.

replaceDefaultPolicyVersionParams.documentation: Parameters to define a mitigation action that adds a blank policy to restrict permissions.

enableIoTLoggingParams.documentation: Parameters to define a mitigation action that enables Amazon Web Services IoT Core logging at a specified level of detail.

publishFindingToSnsParams.documentation: Parameters to define a mitigation action that publishes findings to Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS. You can implement your own custom actions in response to the Amazon SNS messages.

MitigationActionParams.documentation: The set of parameters for this mitigation action. You can specify only one type of parameter (in other words, you can apply only one action for each defined mitigation action).

propagatingAttributes.documentation: An object that represents the propagating thing attributes and the connection attributes.

Mqtt5Configuration.documentation: The configuration to add user-defined properties to enrich MQTT 5 messages.

username.documentation: The value of the username key in an MQTT authorization request.

password.documentation: The value of the password key in an MQTT authorization request.

clientId.documentation: The value of the clientId key in an MQTT authorization request.

MqttContext.documentation: Specifies the MQTT context to use for the test authorizer request

payloadFormatIndicator.documentation:
An Enum string value that indicates whether the payload is formatted as UTF-8.

Valid values are UNSPECIFIED_BYTES and UTF8_DATA.

For more information, see Payload Format Indicator from the MQTT Version 5.0 specification.

Supports substitution templates.

contentType.documentation:
A UTF-8 encoded string that describes the content of the publishing message.

For more information, see Content Type from the MQTT Version 5.0 specification.

Supports substitution templates.

responseTopic.documentation:
A UTF-8 encoded string that's used as the topic name for a response message. The response topic is used to describe the topic which the receiver should publish to as part of the request-response flow. The topic must not contain wildcard characters.

For more information, see Response Topic from the MQTT Version 5.0 specification.

Supports substitution templates.

correlationData.documentation:
The base64-encoded binary data used by the sender of the request message to identify which request the response message is for when it's received.

For more information, see Correlation Data from the MQTT Version 5.0 specification.

This binary data must be based64-encoded.

Supports substitution templates.

messageExpiry.documentation:
A user-defined integer value that will persist a message at the message broker for a specified amount of time to ensure that the message will expire if it's no longer relevant to the subscriber. The value of messageExpiry represents the number of seconds before it expires. For more information about the limits of messageExpiry, see Amazon Web Services IoT Core message broker and protocol limits and quotas from the Amazon Web Services Reference Guide.

Supports substitution templates.

userProperties.documentation: An array of key-value pairs that you define in the MQTT5 header.

MqttHeaders.documentation: Specifies MQTT Version 5.0 headers information. For more information, see MQTT from Amazon Web Services IoT Core Developer Guide.

NonCompliantResource.documentation: Information about the resource that was noncompliant with the audit check.

fileType.documentation: An integer value you can include in the job document to allow your devices to identify the type of file received from the cloud.

codeSigning.documentation: The code signing method of the file.

attributes.documentation: A list of name-attribute pairs. They won't be sent to devices as a part of the Job document.

OTAUpdateFile.documentation: Describes a file to be associated with an OTA update.

creationDate.documentation: The date when the OTA update was created.

lastModifiedDate.documentation: The date when the OTA update was last updated.

protocols.documentation: The protocol used to transfer the OTA update image. Valid values are [HTTP], [MQTT], [HTTP, MQTT]. When both HTTP and MQTT are specified, the target device can choose the protocol.

awsJobExecutionsRolloutConfig.documentation: Configuration for the rollout of OTA updates.

awsJobPresignedUrlConfig.documentation: Configuration information for pre-signed URLs. Valid when protocols contains HTTP.

targetSelection.documentation: Specifies whether the OTA update will continue to run (CONTINUOUS), or will be complete after all those things specified as targets have completed the OTA update (SNAPSHOT). If continuous, the OTA update may also be run on a thing when a change is detected in a target. For example, an OTA update will run on a thing when the thing is added to a target group, even after the OTA update was completed by all things originally in the group.

otaUpdateFiles.documentation: A list of files associated with the OTA update.

awsIotJobId.documentation: The IoT job ID associated with the OTA update.

awsIotJobArn.documentation: The IoT job ARN associated with the OTA update.

errorInfo.documentation: Error information associated with the OTA update.

transferredTo.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account to which the transfer was made.

defaultVersionName.documentation: The name of the default package version.
